item.title: Setting Up Academic Theme
item.description:
Academic theme is great, well-thought in design and popular with users. Did pay up for a coffee on paypal.

I’m migrating from a Jekyll-based CV theme (was a good start and helped to sort out information, but did never lead to new contacts and was not extensible, did set up once, rarely updated).

Some personal notes on setup: - contacts section configurtion explained in Leslie Myint blog post - addeded StackOverflow icon - moved several files (including .sh) to ignore folder - makes cleaner root of repository - disabling people and groups - probably good for another, collaborative site - what is the difference between tags and categories? - https://formspree.io contact for will need activation

Disabled:

  • publications, featured (duplicated, not filled yet)
  • skills (great look, had it in Jekyll CV, but how do you access + must move off the front page)
  • accomplishments (must put a list of econometrics courses in)
  • talks (would be nice to recollect!)
  • experience (to fill later, was not filled in a CV)
  • what is hero for?

I first disabled the blog and thought it was such an archaic activity - writing a blog, but now I see it as a form of notetaking and knowledge management. And the best way of managing some knowledge is:

The most effective way to share knowledge within your organization is to share it with the whole world

— Chris Whong (@chris_whong) March 14, 2019

Todo

  • add personal photo in .png
  • build and put to Github pages
  • use lighthouse repo to sort out topics

Later

Design: - replace favicon

Content: - publications - talks - presentations - tutorials and courses - bilingual

Hosting: - build on AWS Amplify - new domain - domain e-mail (?)

Also is documentation web site blocking traffic from Russia? A provider thing or site configuration? Had to use a proxy to access https://sourcethemes.com/academic.
